key_title: Key to the species of Baumea

source.author: Wilson, K.L.
source.title: Cyperaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Wilson, K.L. (1994). Cyperaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaf-blades flat or 4-angled in cross-section, or all reduced to flattened mucros on sheaths
Leaf-blades terete or oval in cross-section (rarely somewhat angular or flattened at apex)
All leaves reduced to flattened mucros; culms 1–3-noded
Basal leaves well-developed (cauline leaves reduced if present); culms nodeless or 1-(rarely 2)-noded
Leaves square to rhomboid (occasionally narrowly so) in cross-section, faces concave or occasionally flat
Leaves flattened (at least near apex in B. rubiginosa) or narrow-rhomboid, faces flat or convex
Leaves scabrous, with raised'midrib'even if otherwise flat
Spikelets 1-flowered; glumes 3 or 4; inflorescence 2–6 cm long (rarely to 14 cm), no more than 1 cm dia
Spikelets 2–5-flowered; glumes 4 or 5; inflorescence usually 15–40 cm long (occasionally as short as 7 cm), 1–2.5 cm dia
Nut straw-coloured to red-brown; culms nodeless; leaves flat throughout; spikelets ± few, spread out on long branches
Nut bright orange (paler red-brown when immature); culms 1–2-noded (rarely nodeless); leaves often terete near base; spikelets numerous, in dense discrete clusters
Leaves pith-filled, occasionally irregularly transversely septate
Spikelets few, not in dense clusters, 1-flowered; glumes 2–4 (mostly 3)

Nut straw-coloured to whitish, with acute apex, triquetrous, 2.0–2.5 mm long, 1.0–1.3 mm diam.; spikelets spaced ± evenly along branches; leaf-blades and involucral bracts terete and obviously transversely septate when dry

Nut pale red-brown to bright orange at maturity, with obtuse apex, obscurely trigonous, 2.2–4.0 mm long, 1.2–2.0 mm diam.; spikelets usually in dense, discrete clusters on inflorescence branches; leaf-blades and involucral bracts flattened at least at apex, not appearing septate when dry
